comments.commentBody:
One point: The pine tar game was different.

That was a rules interpretation. The AL commissioner (If I'm correct it was the league commissioner and not Bowie Kuhn), as I recall, ruled that the umpire failed to uphold the "spirit" of the rule. Excess pine tar did not help Brett hit the home run, thus there was no valid reason to take it away other than on a technicality, and that was not in the spirit of fair competition.

This of course is a safe/out call, just a basic meat and potatoes blown call, for which there is no precedent in baseball history of a reversal.

And of course it opens up Pandora's Box.

But in the absence of replay to assist that call, and with the ump's full and unambiguous confession that he blew the call, a precedent could be established here.

Simply: It would have been the last play of the game, if called correctly. The precedent can simply be this: In the case of irrefutable evidence that the ump got the call wrong on the last play of the game, the league can overturn the call. Now of course you would expect that to be used to change a stolen loss into a deserved win or a fair tie, but in this case it could be used to award an earned honor.

All of that is in the best interests of the game and is in the spirit of fair competition. Because the decision can be drawn narrowly and applied to a very rare circumstance (a blown call on a potential game-ending play is just plain rare), and because that is a circumstance worthy of league review...

I say let's get this done.

If only we as citizens were as consumed with protecting our Constitution as we the sheep are engaged in righting the statistical wrongs suffered by a small group of millionaires who lure us to their taxpayer-funded palaces with "E-Saver" promotions of $80 so we can have the privilege of paying $6.00 for a hot dog.

Questionable call?

It was a bad call.

A missed call.

A blown call.

What is wrong with journalists and editors that they can't just say what is, is. They have to parse it, divide it, massage it, empty it of value.

I swear, I know this isn't the normal venue, but this is why traditional journalism is so worthless, and dying.

If they do this on something so clear cut we can all see, what do they do with complex political and foreign policy matters that we're not familiar with.

OK. I'm done.

The Commissioner should make a special ruling that this guy gets the perfect game in the books. One-time thing. No other situation like it.

so bad, it's almost not worth discussing.

http://www.badref.com

Either way, the pitcher has a special niche in baseball history. If the call is reversed he becomes the first to record a perfect game by that means. If not, Armando joins Harvey Haddix as one of the only two guys to pitch a "perfect, but" game.

As a boy, I listened to the Haddix game on the radio -- 12 perfect innings, each more exquisitely nervous-making than the one before, then a loss to the Braves in the 13th. At the time, I was crushed; I felt so bad for Harvey Haddix. But now I think: he'll always be remembered for that. If he had pitched a regular nine-inning perfecto he'd be one of the bunch of guys whose names have become little noted nor easily recalled by most.

Was the ump wrong? Looks like he was.
Was the pitcher robbed? Seems so.
Does this rise to the level where we should waste another second worrying about it? No.

It's just a game, folks.

This sort of baseball umpiring has been going on for years - ever since Bud Selig became commissioner and allowed the umpires to run their own show. They now not only choose and train their own without MLB interference, they give themselves vacation time off during the season. When you only need to work maybe nine months out of the year what's with that? When owners look at attendance figures and groan ask me and thousands of other fans around the country why we don't go to games or even watch them on TV any more. It isn't the same game it used to be and the umpiring is a prime factor in ruining it. If the owners were smart they would buy out whatever contract they have with the umpires and go to their local rent-an-ump for a lot less money.
What is taking Selig so long?

What about that call was questionable? He was OUT. He was out by a half step - a country mile at first base. The Ump himself even admitted this after seeing the replay.

I can understand NOT wanting to review a regular season game (anyone remember the NHL's crease rule of the late '90's?), but given the technology (HD & instant replay) -- Playoff games and career defining moments like this SHOULD be reviewed.

We all know what happened here, and the record should reflect the facts, not some archaic legacy of error, based on sports of the 19th Century.

Make it right Bud.

PS - Galarraga was a class act at the end.
OK, the ump realizes his mistake and admits same.  Why can't the call be corrected and the game be awarded to Mr. Galarraga?  If the rules don't allow that then the rules need to be changed.......

Armando Galarraga is a mensch. The ump feels miserable about this, but I don't envision anything being done about it. Let's hope this mistake will spur Major League Baseball to hurry up and widen the parameters for using instant replay in the future.

comments.userDisplayName: Phil in the mountains of Kyushu
comments.commentBody:
What this up is bidding for another job?

When umps interfere with the decent play of people -- when they register opinions and rulings totally apart from the realities of human action -- it's clear they're just modeling themselves after the Supreme Court. As it, in its infamous Citizens United case, elevated all the arrogance of corporate power over the human, so this ump must obviously be signalling his availability for any federal judgeship to continue U.S. nationwide and worldwide most foul ball.

Well, this one was a really speedy solve. Perhaps because I first had PICOOHM, the change to MICROHM didn't faze me. (I'm not sure I would have known to drop an o otherwise.) In difficulty, more like a Tuesday, I think, although the ROFL bit is impressive...if you know the expression (which I didn't remember until googling). HAJI is also showing up a lot lately.

..."The issues in the primary have basically been which Republican dislikes government most. During the Tuesday debate, Bauer claimed that illegal immigration was caused by lavish government welfare payments, which caused poor people to refuse to do manual labor. Haley bragged that she had opposed the federal stimulus program. The attorney general, Henry McMaster, who is currently suing to try to stop the federal government from bringing health care reform to South Carolina, attributed the failures of the state’s public schools to teachers’ being so busy “filling out federal forms that they can’t teach.”

This is too crazy to be funny, Gail! If South Carolina votes in one of these nutcases in the Fall election, they may well end up behind Alabama and Mississipi as the most backward state! Best case scenario, maybe they will vote to secede! We could have a fairly sane country without Texas, Alabama and South Carolina. The residents who do not hate our government could elect to move elsewhere. I am sure the government would be willing to subsidize their move, because it is in the best interests of our growth and sanity.

Another possibility, Sarah and Todd will find Alaska too darn cold and will move their brood to South Carolina--where Sarah can run for governor! She can take her sister, too, and leave that no-count brother-in-law back in Alaska to do some drillin'!

Gail, dear Gail, I do so love your columns but this one really disappoints. Today Jane Lubcheco, NOAA Undersecretary was in denial about the submerged oil plumes in the Gulf of Texaco. I was so looking forward to see the results of your sharp pen taking her to task for spinning like a top for BP. Gail, we out here in ordinary-land don't give a whit about the numbskulls in South Carolina. We are far more worried about our friends and neighbors along the Gulf coast and even more so about the future of the Gulf.

Gail, we need every great columnist, and you are one in my humble opinion, to focus on what's happening in the gulf but even more so, what's happening with those who have their hands on the levers of government power, like Ms. Lubchenco.

No, we don't want "instant replay!"  It's only a game, and in any game players as well as umpires make "errors."  I feel bad for Galarraga, but still, it's only a game, and for that matter, let's dispense with the "designated hitter."

What makes me more mad than the tape delay (since I am at work, I have to watch the matches at night anyway) is that the NY Times sent me today, unsolicited, e-mails announcing the result of the Stosur-Williams match.  I don't understand why the Times does this.  I have not selected Sports alerts from its menu, only "Breaking News."  Why the quarterfinal of the French Open is breaking news is beyond me!  The Times should recognize that most people have to watch sports when they get home from work and do so via DVRs.  The Times should not send ANY sports scores to its subscribers unless they specifically ask for sports scores.

I hope Stosur can do it. I really like her low-key, determined, and fundamentally tough but fair way of conducting herself. She is a real sportswoman, as opposed merely an athlete. Jankovic is very different, from my perspective.
Also, as the writer points out, she has earned her path to the final the hard way. I hope she has enough left in the tank. Come on, Sam!

Human error is part of the game, if it is made by the players or managers. No ref should ever be part of the game, especially like this. Why not eliminate error when possible? Anyhow, baseball is a bit of a joke, especially for a sport whose devout followers are so devoted to "facts." How many times would replay show missed bags, not by runners but the defense, or expose calls much, much closer than this one, or show missed tags? I bet a significant amount.

What interests me is the thought process that lead to the umpire's error.  I believe that he was determined to show his integrity by not awarding a cheap out just because a perfect game was on the line.  Unfortunately, his determination was so strong that he ended up doing the opposite.  It's a mistake that all of us have made at one time or another.

If the mistake was so obvious that the umpire himself realised it, why didn't the whole crew confer and the crew chief reverse the call?  To leave a bad call, that you know is a bad call, stand is simply an injustice and a blight on the baseball record book.  What do those supposed accomplishments mean when we know that at least some of them are bogus?  This guy pitched a perfect game and should get credit for it.  The record books should reflect this, irrespective of what it said on the scoreboard.  Otherwise, it's all garbage and why should I continue to care about garbage?  Straighten this out, Selig.

All in all, a good editorial. One point, though. No attempt to convince Iran to give up nuclear arms will be successful--or even morally coherent--unless Israel is also convinced to give up its nuclear forces. What we should be striving for is a nuclear-free Middle East, not one in which one side is allowed to maintain a nuclear arsenal while denying that it has any. Is it any wonder that Iran sees Western attempts to strong-arm it as hypocritical? As the raid on the flotilla has shown, Israel is no more "reasonable" or "responsible" in its decision-making or its use of force than any other player in the region. Fair is fair, and all sides should be treated equally.

"That’s not security; that’s a travesty." The real questions is why is the US choose to unconditionally support Israel no matter what it does. They are determined to shoot themselves in the foot, and US along also.
President Obama has not shown any courage on any major issue, why now?

It does seem like we've got something in the water down here. The most disturbing part of this article isn't the sex-capades of Nikki Haley, it's the absurd fight about which candidate is the most anti-government. South Carolina is a very poor place fallen on hard times all around. This is no time for this kind of sheenanigans. They need government, not retro-ideological haggling...

“Here we are in this very poor state that needs help very much,” said Mark Tompkins, a professor of political science at the University of South Carolina. “We’re sixth in the nation in unemployment, and we’re fighting about whether the federal government can help us with health care.”

I'd have to believe this is a serious problem for States, with the New Healthcare Act, $500 Billion Dollars is going to be stripped from Medicare to pay for this Healthcare plan. That's $50 Billion a year or $961 Million a week that seniors are now going to have to come up with in out-of-pocket expenses, just to keep the same coverage they now enjoy.

Healthcare is not a forgotten issue.
